items.title: UN High Seas Treaty to take effect, protecting two-thirds of ocean

featured_image.name: Protecting the High Seas: Ensuring Strong, Effective MPAs Under ...

items.description:
The United Nations High Seas Treaty, formally known as the Biodiversity Beyond National Jurisdiction (BBNJ) Agreement, will officially enter into force on January 17, 2026, establishing the first legally binding international framework to protect marine biodiversity in nearly two-thirds of the world's ocean.[1][2][3]

The treaty becomes international law after Morocco became the 60th nation to ratify it on September 19, 2025, triggering a 120-day countdown to implementation. Currently, 82 countries have officially joined the agreement, and 145 of the UN's 193 member states have signed it.[2][4][5][1]

items.title: Live: Shock as Tszyu-Zefara grudge match called off after accidental headbutt
items.description: Nikita Tszyu and Michael Zerafa hotly anticipated fight is abandoned after the second round as the crowd vents its frustration at the Brisbane Entertainment Centre. Follow live.

items.title: MIT team cools trapped ions 10 times below standard limit

featured_image.name: Ion traps – DLR Quantum Computing Initiative

items.description:
Two separate research efforts published this week are advancing the frontiers of quantum computing by solving distinct challenges: achieving efficient cooling for chip-based systems and discovering unexpected quantum states in exotic materials.

Researchers at MIT and MIT Lincoln Laboratory announced Wednesday a technique for cooling trapped ions using integrated photonics that reaches temperatures about 10 times below the standard laser cooling limit, known as the Doppler limit. The method achieves this in approximately 100 microseconds, several times faster than existing approaches.[1][2][3]

Meanwhile, scientists at TU Wien in Vienna and Rice University revealed Tuesday in Nature Physics that they observed an "emergent topological semimetal" — a quantum state previously considered impossible because it combines two phenomena thought to be incompatible.[4][5][6]

items.title: Foreign fishing vessel filmed 100m away from Queensland coast
items.description: Locals on Queensland's far north tip have shared their account after seeing an Indonesian fishing boat within a stone's throw of the mainland.

items.title: Former South Korean president jailed over martial law declaration
items.description: Former South Korean president Yoon Suk Yeol is sentenced to five years in jail over crimes relating to his failed attempt at imposing martial law in the country.

items.title: Cars floating out to sea, campers fleeing: Is this all climate change in action?
items.description: When it comes to extreme rainfall, it is hard for climate scientists to say what's natural and what's caused by climate change. But they do know the most extreme events are dropping more rain, more often. This is why.

items.title: Tim Picton's alleged attacker accused of another assault, posting it on Snapchat
items.description: The man accused of assaulting former Labor strategist Tim Picton allegedly knocked another man unconscious two days prior.

items.title: Venezuela's acting president calls for oil reforms, US thaw

featured_image.name: Venezuela's Rodriguez proposes oil reform to ease investment

items.description:
Less than two weeks after the United States military captured Nicolás Maduro, Venezuela's acting president used her first major address to lawmakers to call for sweeping reforms to the country's oil industry and a diplomatic thaw with Washington.

In a 44-minute state of the union speech on Thursday, Delcy Rodríguez urged Venezuela's National Assembly to approve changes to the nation's hydrocarbon law that would open doors to greater foreign investment in the state-controlled oil sector. The address marked a striking departure from the anti-American rhetoric that defined her predecessor's rule.[1][2]

items.title: Can Machado actually transfer the Nobel Peace Prize to Trump?
items.description: While it can be gifted, refused or displayed, the Nobel Peace Prize itself — once awarded — belongs to its original recipient forever.

items.title: Top faith leaders urge PM to scrap new racial hatred offence
items.description: A broad of coalition of Australia's most influential religious leaders have urged the prime minister to scrap Labor's proposal to outlaw the promotion of racial hatred.

items.title: Once top secret, Greenland's only US military base is stirring trouble
items.description: Here is what we know about the US military footprint in Greenland, and how the increase of troops from Denmark and its allies stacks up.

items.title: Israeli startup nT-Tao fires first plasma in compact fusion reactor

featured_image.name: Israeli nuclear fusion firm fires first plasma in two months toward 20 ...

items.description:
Israeli compact fusion energy company nT-Tao announced on January 15, 2026 that its C3 prototype has successfully fired its first plasma pulses, reaching operational status just over two months after assembly began. The milestone represents a concrete advancement in the company's pursuit of a container-sized fusion reactor capable of generating 10-20 MW of clean power.[1][2]

The Hod Hasharon-based startup's C3 system builds directly upon the successful experimental campaign of its predecessor, the C2-A, which achieved plasma temperatures of approximately one million degrees Celsius—roughly 100 electron volts—at the intended high-density regime. The new prototype incorporates design refinements across magnets, pulsed power systems, diagnostics, and overall integration, with experimental goals focused on reaching higher temperatures and extended confinement durations.[3][2][4]

items.title: Einstein's wormholes may be time bridges, not space tunnels

featured_image.name: Wormholes may not exist – we've found they reveal something ...

items.description:
Wormholes, long imagined as cosmic tunnels for interstellar travel and time machines, may not exist as shortcuts through space at all. Instead, new research suggests that Einstein-Rosen bridges—the mathematical structures behind the wormhole concept—represent something more fundamental: connections between two opposing directions of time.

A paper published this week in the journal Classical and Quantum Gravity by astrophysicist Enrique Gaztañaga and colleagues presents a reinterpretation of the original 1935 work by Albert Einstein and Nathan Rosen. The researchers argue that the popular conception of wormholes arose from a misunderstanding of what the physicists intended.[1][2]

items.title: Trump announces 'Board of Peace' to oversee Gaza governance

featured_image.name: Trump says he plans to name Gaza Board of Peace early next ...

items.description:
President Donald Trump announced Thursday that the "Board of Peace" for Gaza has been officially formed, moving forward with the second phase of his 20-point plan to end the conflict in the Palestinian territory. The announcement came via his Truth Social platform, one day after his special envoy Steve Witkoff declared the launch of the plan's next stage.[1][2][3]

"It is my Great Honor to announce that THE BOARD OF PEACE has been formed," Trump wrote, adding that the body's members would be revealed "shortly." He called it "the Greatest and Most Prestigious Board ever assembled at any time, any place."[4][5]

items.title: Chinese universities claim 8 of top 10 spots in global research rankings

featured_image.name: China's expanding role in global higher education rankings ...

items.description:
Zhejiang University has claimed the top spot in the Leiden Rankings, a global measure of research productivity, pushing Harvard to third place and marking a shift in academic power that reflects both China's strategic investments in science and the mounting financial pressures facing American higher education.

The rankings, produced by the Centre for Science and Technology Studies at Leiden University in the Netherlands, now feature eight Chinese institutions in the top 10. Twenty years ago, only one Chinese school would have made the top 25.[1][2][3]

items.title: Australian who escaped Iran says the protests — and the crackdown — are 'different this time'
items.description: On a visit to his home town outside Tehran, this Iranian Australian joined the protests last Thursday night, then the regime's suppression methods turned from tear gas to live fire.

items.title: Scientists map hidden landscape beneath Antarctica's ice

featured_image.name: New map of Antarctica reveals hidden world of lakes, valleys ...

items.description:
A team of international scientists has produced the most comprehensive map yet of Antarctica's concealed terrain, revealing thousands of previously unknown hills, ridges, and river channels buried beneath miles of ice. The breakthrough, published Thursday in the journal Science, could transform researchers' ability to predict how the frozen continent will respond to climate change and contribute to rising sea levels.[1][2][3]

The map uncovers geological features spanning 2 to 30 kilometers beneath the ice sheet, which covers more than 5.4 million square miles. Among the discoveries are deep alpine valleys, extensive channels carved by ancient flowing water that stretch for hundreds of kilometers, and sharp transitions between highland and lowland terrain that may indicate tectonic boundaries.[4][3][1]

items.title: IMF awaits shareholder backing before aiding Venezuela
items.description:
The International Monetary Fund stands ready to support Venezuela, but must first receive backing from its major shareholders to recognize the country's post-Maduro leadership before any assistance can flow, Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva said Thursday.

"If there is an opportunity to support the people of Venezuela, you can be sure the Fund will be there," Georgieva told Reuters during a visit to Ukraine. The remarks came nearly two weeks after U.S. forces removed former President Nicolás Maduro in a January 3 military operation, leaving acting President Delcy Rodríguez to navigate the country's economic turmoil.[1][2][3][4]

items.title: Interstellar comet's sunward jets baffle scientists

featured_image.name: Rare interstellar comet 3i/Atlas set to fly past Earth ...

items.description:
The third known interstellar object to visit our solar system continues to puzzle astronomers as it exits toward Jupiter, displaying sunward jets that defy conventional comet physics while yielding no detectable alien signals to radio telescopes scanning for signs of extraterrestrial technology.

Comet 3I/ATLAS, first spotted on July 1, 2025, by the NASA-funded ATLAS survey in Chile, has been the subject of intense scientific scrutiny since its discovery. With the Breakthrough Listen project confirming no technosignatures were detected during five hours of observation using the Green Bank Telescope on December 18, 2025, researchers have largely settled the question of whether this cosmic wanderer might be artificial.[1][2][3]

"We all would have been thrilled to find technosignatures coming from 3I/ATLAS, but they're just not there," Benjamin Jacobson-Bell from the University of California, Berkeley, told Space.com. "Finding no signals was the result we expected, due to the significant evidence for 3I/ATLAS being a comet with only natural features."[4]

items.title: Trump accepts Nobel medal from Machado 'for the work I have done'
items.description: The US president says he has accepted María Corina Machado's Nobel Peace Prize at a meeting in the White House, on account of "the work I have done".
